column1: '''Rushey''' was a small village south of the [[Marish]]
column2: in the [[Eastfarthing]] of [[the Shire]].<ref name=Part/> It was built on a relatively stable ground amidst the soggy fens of the Marish
column3: hence the name.<ref name="Nomen"/> The [[Causeway]] traversed the village
column4: connecting it to the villages of [[Stock]] to the north and [[Deephallow]] to the south.<ref name=Part>{{FR|Part}}</ref>

column1: The name means "Rush-isle". [[David Salo]] has suggested an [[Old English|Old Hobbitish]] etymology from *''Ryscieg''.<ref name=Salo>{{webcite|author=[[David Salo]]|articleurl=http://groups.yahoo.com/group/elfling/message/121|articlename=Hobbitish Place-names|dated=23 November 1998|website=[[Elfling]]}}</ref> ''[[Wiktionary:ey#Old_Norse|-ey]]'' or ''-y'' in English place-names has the sense "small island"
It was called so as "''a 'hard' among the fens of the Marish''"<ref name="Nomen">{{HM|N}}
column2: p. 775</ref> forming an isolated "island" in the midst of the soggy ground; this nomenclature is also seen in the [[Wikipedia:Isle of Ely|Isle of Ely]].<ref name=Salo/>

column1: The name is spelled as "Rushy" on [[A Part of the Shire]].<ref name=Part/><ref name=Salo/>

column2: towns and villages of the Shire]]
